title: Core Content Policies
text:
Wikipedia aims to represent all of the information and views on a topic or person that have been published in reliable sources. It is up to you to distinguish reliable sources from unreliable sources, and to distinguish opinion from fact.
If a person or topic is controversial, represent the facts of the controversy: what are the sides and what is the evidence on each side. In your writing, attribute opinions to the person whose opinions they are and state facts without attribution. For example, it is a fact that Nettie Stevens was a geneticist, but it is Richardson’s opinion that one of the most impressive things Stevens did was to participate in debates about sex determination. So you would say something like this:


Nettie Stevens was a geneticist who made important contributions to the chromosomal theory of sex in the first decade of the twentieth century. The historian of science Sarah Richardson has argued that her “role as a bold contestant in theoretical debates over the mechanism of sex determination…despite her meager platform as a research associate at a suburban women’s college” is “the most overlooked and impressive dimension of Stevens’s contribution to the chromosomal theory of sex.”


Facts should, nonetheless, be footnoted to establish their verifiability. Do not give your own opinion unless it has already been published in a reliable source. When presenting opposing views on a topic or person, make clear how much support or evidence each side has. For example there is much more evidence that vaccines prevent disease than that they cause injury, so you would not present these sides of the vaccine debate as if they were equal. The weight given to a view should represent the quantity of evidence for it and number of people who hold it. As much as possible, present controversies in an impartial tone rather than quoting people on either side.

title: Core Content Policies
text:
Verifiability
All information should come from reliable sources, and all statements should be verifiable, even if you do not include a citation for each one. Citations are required for quotations, statements that have been or are likely to be challenged, and anything potentially contentious about a living or recently deceased person. If you find unsubstantiated statements in existing articles, you can add a {{citation needed}} tag, or add a citation yourself. Exceptional claims need multiple high-quality sources.
Wikipedia classifies peer-reviewed academic publications as the most reliable, but respected mainstream publications are also considered reliable, especially newspapers with editorial oversight and a professional structure for fact-checking. Self-published sources (where the author publishes the source themself) are not reliable, but may be used to a limited degree for biographies of living individuals. Wikipedia may not be used as a source, unless Wikipedia itself is being discussed in the article, though you should link to other Wikipedia pages when possible.
A source does not need to be publicly accessible in order to be referenced. Non-English references may be used, but English-language sources are preferred.
Do not plagiarize! Information from sources must be rewritten in your own words or directly quoted.

title: Core Content Policies
text:
No Original Research
Anything you write must be clearly and directly supported by published sources. Do not synthesize sources to make an original argument not stated by any of the sources. Do not use unpublished sources, such as archival documents, court records, interviews that you do yourself, etc.

title: Getting Started
text:
The first thing you will need to do is Create an account on Wikipedia. To protect your privacy and avoid harassment, I recommend against using your real name or an account name related to your real name.
Once you have created your account, go ahead and log in. You then have the option of creating a user page, which you can navigate to by clicking the link with your username in the upper left or entering the url en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:<your user name>. From there, you can get to your Talk page, which is where you will receive updates on articles you create. Other users can send you comments and messages there.

title: Getting Started
text:
Enable Visual Editing
Most of you will want to edit and write pages using the visual editor, which is much like a word processor, rather than editing the source pages. To enable visual editing, in the upper right of your screen, click on the person icon, then choose Preferences. On the next screen, choose Editing, then check the box next to “Enable the visual editor” (you may need to scroll down).

title: Editing Existing Pages
text:
Editing existing pages is a good way to practice working with the Wikipedia interface. Once you have made at least ten edits over more than four days, you will be able to publish your own articles. To find articles to edit, examine a variety of pages for:

Places where you can add verifiable information
Spelling or grammar errors
Passages you can re-word for clarity or neutrality
Opportunities to add links to other Wikipedia pages

You might start with topics or people you are interested in or know about, or check Wikipedia’s list of articles that need updating or Wikipedia’s Task Center.

title: Editing Existing Pages
text:
Start Editing
Once you find a page you would like to edit, click one of the Edit links on the page. You can then get started typing. You can use the editing toolbar or keyboard shortcuts for formatting. To add links to other Wikipedia pages, highlight the text you would like to link, and click on the link icon in the editing toolbar. Suggestions will begin to drop down; choose the correct one. To add references, place the cursor where you would like the footnote to go (this will usually be after the period at the end of a sentence). Then click on the quotation marks icon. If you have a URL, DOI, or ISBN for your source, you can choose “Automatic” and paste that in; otherwise, choose “Manual” and type the information in.
When you are finished editing, click Publish and add a brief description of your edits.

title: Biographies
text:
If the person is still alive, write the biography in the present tense; otherwise write in the past tense. Use “former” to indicate retirement if the person is still alive. Overall, present the biography in chronological order.
The first section should briefly summarize the person’s life and works, and establish their notability. The first sentence should include their full name and job title or field of research, dates of birth and death, location of their work, and the main reason they are notable. Previous nationalities and/or country of birth should not be included in this section unless relevant to the person’s notability. Job title or field of research should not be capitalized if it is a common noun (e.g., “biologist”).
After the first sentence, a person should be referred to by their surname (family name) only (without Dr. or Ms. or Professor), or by a pronoun. Use pronouns that match the person’s most recent self-identification. For a trans or non-binary person, use their current name only.
For more, see the Wikipedia Manual of Style.

title: Biographies
text:
Caution Regarding Living Subjects
Biographies of living people are particularly sensitive, and all information must be absolutely correct and well-sourced. Please be mindful of the person’s privacy and do not include any information that could harm them if made public. Stick to the facts and do not use language that implies value judgment, unless it comes from a reliable source. For people who are not well-known, include only material relevant to their notability. Be very careful with material that might harm a person’s reputation.
Self-published sources are fine if they are written by the person themself, is not unduly self-serving, and does not involve claims about other people. You can use the person’s social media account to verify things like date of birth. Do not discuss the person’s religion or sexual orientation unless the person has publicly self-identified with the religion or orientation, or if these are relevant to their notability.
A living person accused of a crime should be presumed innocent until convicted in a court of law.

title: Writing Your Article
text:
When you are ready to start drafting your article, go to Wikipedia’s Article Wizard. After you click through some information, you will be able to give your article a title. This should be the name by which your scientist is best known.
To use the visual editor, click Create, which should be right under your title. The first thing you should do is create a References section. To do this, click the drop-down arrow next to “Paragraph” in the toolbar and select “Heading.” Type the word “References.” When you add footnotes, they will automatically go there, but you won’t see them until you publish.
To get started, place your cursor above your new “References” section and type your lead paragraph. When you are done, click Publish. This will only save your draft; it will not become public.
As you write your draft, be sure to save often.

title: Writing Your Article
text:
Publishing Your Article
Once you have made at least ten edits over a period of at least four days, you will be an autoconfirmed user and you can publish your own article. To do this, on the draft page, click the Move link on the right. In the dropdown under “New title,” change the selection from “Draft” to “(Article).” Under “Reason,” choose “Move to mainspace.”
If you are not an autoconfirmed user, I can publish your article for you.
